description:
Step 1:
Import the Flatpak into your Steam Library, then go into the game's 'properties' settings, then in the launch options, add this (without the quote marks)

e.g "flatpak run io.github.fabiangreffrath.Doom -iwad ~/DOOM.WAD"

Or whatever doom wad you happen to be running, and yes, place all Doom WAD's in your home directory in Dolphin (file manager).

Bonus, start the game and then exit if you want to follow the optional steps below.

Step 2 (optional):
Widescreen Assets for that work out of the box can be found here:

https://github.com/nashmuhandes/WidePix

Take the assets from the id.doom folders (depending on the game) and go to (without the quote marks:

"/home/deck/.var/app/io.github.fabiangreffrath.Doom/data/crispy-doom/autoload"

And if you've already launched the game in step one, there should be three folders "doom-all" "doom.wad" and "doom2.wad", so import the necessary assets from the Widepix folder into the matching .wad folder there. (Note: the doom-all folder will affect all Doom wads you use, while doom.wad and doom2.wad only affect those specific games)

Step 3 (optional):

Roland SC-55 music packs for Doom 1 and Doom 2 can be found here:

https://sc55.duke4.net/games.php

Just unzip the music files into the music-packs folder (also located at "/home/deck/.var/app/io.github.fabiangreffrath.Doom/data/crispy-doom/") and place the raw music files directly there.

Alternatively, I'd recommend checking out (for Doom 1 atleast) the 32x Resurrection fan remixes, which can be found here:

https://www.doomworld.com/forum/topic/132062-doom-32x-resurrection-ost-doom-2/

For this, copy the wad file and music folder into the early mentioned auto-load folder and place the appropriate music wad and folder into 'doom.wad' or 'doom2.wad' depending on which remix for which game you are using.
summary: A Nice Vanilla Doom Experience in Widescreen

I found Crispy Doom while looking for a source port that could handle John Romero's Sigil. I had been using Chocolate Doom, but wanted to find an engine that could support the additional object counts in advanced maps. A lot of people use GZDoom, but it strays so far from the classic experience that the first time I used it, I thought "this is not Doom."

Since Crispy Doom is based on Chocolate Doom, but with a few modifications to remove the original engine's limitations on object counts and offer higher screen resolutions, I think it is the perfect balance of classic fidelity and modern features.
summary: The best source port for playing classic Doom, Doom 2, and Sigil

This could be the best Doom Sourceport on this platform. It's main competitor GZDoom, while allowing far more fancy WADs and modern graphics ehancements can't compete with the accurary of this version.

Howerever unfortunately this Flathub version seemlingly wasn't compiled with FluidSynth included meaning it lacks proper MIDI playback on Linux via soundfonts. You have to live with OPL3 or GUS which is ok but the tracks where not designed for that. I can't be overstated how important music is for the feel of classic Doom. It's just as important as the graphics and gunplay in my opinion. Thus I can't give this a better rating until FluidSynth is properly included here.
summary: Could be th best Sourceport option on Flathub

description: This flatpak is configured in a frustrating way. It seems like all of the default behavior for IWAD loading has been stripped out at compile time. It refuses to load IWADs from anywhere automatically, which makes the pile of icons it puts in your launcher useless. You have to specify an IWAD on the command line. It would be much better if it loaded IWADs from the flatpak data or config directories.
